SUNDA(Y)NCE Sometimes, the surface of our Sun seems to dance. In the middle of 2012, for example, NASA's Sun-orbiting Solar Dynamic Observatory spacecraft imaged an impressive prominence that seemed to perform a running dive roll like an acrobatic dancer. The dramatic explosion was captured in ultraviolet light in the featured time-lapse video covering about three hours. A looping magnetic field directed the flow of hot plasma on the Sun. The scale of the dancing prominence is huge -- the entire Earth would easily fit under the flowing arch of hot gas. A quiescent prominence typically lasts about a month and may erupt in a Coronal Mass Ejection (CME), expelling hot gas into the Solar System. The energy mechanism that creates a solar prominence is still a topic of research. Like in 2012, this year the Sun's surface is again quite active and features many filaments and prominences. Giving us a beautiful extraordinary AURORA show second week of may.

Last month, after one year of thoughtful considerations, I applied to add another first name to my already existing names. Our names that we carry, along with their associations, journey alongside us throughout our lives. They leave an indelible mark, shaping our identity. Whether a name becomes a source of empowerment, or a challenge depends on the associations, intentions, and energy embedded within it. It has the potential to be a precious gift influencing how we perceive ourselves. Aurora, also commonly known as northern lights (aurora borealis) or southern lights (aurora australis). The name Aurora mirrors my heritage, weaving together threads of both Australian and Danish descent. The name was suggested to me by my Australian family, who perceived it as a metaphorical embrace of two celestial wonders ‚Äî the northern lights representing my Danish roots and the southern lights representing my Australian. Embracing the name Aurora is not just an addition; it is a signature for a more authentic story. It encapsulates the essence of who I am and serves as a poetic reflection of the diverse influences that define me. Dancing Sky 01. The Celestial Sphere Celestial bodies, like stars, planets, and others, are far away from us, each one at a specific distance from Earth. However, we observe as if all of them lie on the same spherical shell. Such a shell is known as the celestial sphere. On the celestial sphere we are able to measure the apparent position of the celestial bodies, not its true position. In the video below, it is illustrated this difference using eight stars from the Orion constellation.
